Comments.Text: This question might be more appropriate on the dedicated [opendata.SE](http://opendata.stackexchange.com/). That said, I cross my fingers for [dat](http://usodi.org/2014/04/02/dat), which aspires to become a "Git for data".
@ojdo Thanks, I never heard of opendata.SE before, I also found [this](http://opendata.stackexchange.com/q/266/2872) interesting (and very similar) question there.

Hoping it could be useful to anyone, I made a [notebook](https://gist.github.com/akiross/754c7b87a2af8603da78b46cdaaa5598) to explore how convolution and transposed convolution can be used in TensorFlow (0.11). Maybe having some practical examples and figures may help a bit more to understand how they works.
Reserve Bank of India have a huge database about India,\nWorld Bank have huge data set

I havent found any good free comprehensive datasets for typical Business Intelligence applications. The [Microsoft Contoso BI Demo Dataset for Retail Industry from Official Microsoft Download Center](http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=18279) download works with some Microsoft products (see [AndyGett on SharePoint and Other Business Software](http://bl og.bullseyeconsulting.com/archive/2012/08/14/setting-up-sample-contoso-database-for-performancepoint-and-sharepoint.aspx)), but I dont see any plain sql or csv dumps of it, nor any license info.
A great place to find public data sets is http://opendata.stackexchange.com/
Have you joined the Open Data Stack Exchange? http://opendata.stackexchange.com

For me, this page gave me a better explanation it also explains the difference between deconvolution and transpose convolution: https://towardsdatascience.com/types-of-convolutions-in-deep-learning-717013397f4d
Isnt upsampling more like backwards pooling than backwards strided convolution, since it has no parameters?
